title: What time is the Queen’s speech today and who writes it?
text:
The Queen’s Speech is a very formal occasion complete with robes and crown (Picture: Getty Images)

Parliament is set to be formally re-opened this morning with the Queen’s Speech which signals the beginning of the new session in Commons.

The re-opening comes after parliament was prorogued last week, and ahead of a crucial week for Brexit negotiations as Boris Johnson makes his last ditch attempt to secure a deal with the EU.

It’s the first time since June 2017 that there has been a state opening, and it will be the 65th time that the Queen – who will be dressed for the occasion in ceremonial robes and crown – has given such a speech.

But what time is she due to address Commons and who actually writes the speech?

Here’s what you need to know.

What time is the Queen’s Speech in Parliament today?

The Queen is due to deliver her speech to Parliament at 11.30am, following a carriage procession to Westminster.

The Queen delivers a speech which is written for her by government ministers (Picture: Getty Images)

She is expected to lay out 22 bills in the speech, including measures to support the NHS, tackle serious and violent crime and to invest in science and infrastructure.

The speech will be attended by members of the house of Lords as well as judges from the High Court and Court of Appeal, and Justices from the Supreme Court.

MPs will be able to watch the speech from the entrance to the Chamber in Commons.

Who writes the Queen’s Speech?

The speech comes ahead of Boris Johnson’s last-ditch attempt to secure a Brexit deal (Picture: EPA)

The Queen does not write the speech herself, but reads pre-prepared words which are written by Conservative ministers.

It’s been reported that the speech will include details of Boris Johnson’s promise to make the UK ‘the greatest place on Earth’ after Brexit, laying out plans to end the free movement of EU citizens into the UK and provide faster access to medicines.

The prime minister has expressed hopes that the speech will ‘get this country moving again’.

‘The people of this country don’t just want us to sort out Brexit,’ he said.

‘They want their NHS to be stronger, their streets safer, their Wifi faster, the air they breathe cleaner, their kids’ schools better-funded – and this optimistic and ambitious Queen’s Speech sets us on a course to make all that happen, and more besides.

‘After one of the least-active parliaments in living memory, the proposals we are bringing forward will get this country moving again.

‘This is a Queen’s Speech that will deliver for every corner of the UK and make this, once again, the greatest place on earth.’

description: The Queen is set to deliver the Speech at the state re-opening of Parliament - here's what time it's taking place.
